The volcanic eruption in Iceland has triggered an intense effort by scientists to do two things.
One, improve our ability to detect volcanic ash clouds.
And two, forecast their movement in the atmosphere.
Eruptions are surprisingly common, and as NPR's Richard Harris reports, more precise information about them could ultimately make air travel safer.
In the past decade or so, scientists around the world have actually gotten a lot better at detecting and tracking dangerous ash clouds.
Mike Pavolonis at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says it wasn't so long ago that forecasters just eyeballed weather satellite photographs to track plumes.
What we've gone to now more is turning that satellite data into quantitative information, on not just is the ash cloud there but how high is it?
How much ash is there?
What are its physical properties?
Are they large particles, which fall out quicker than small particles?
The satellites now use infrared data, which means they can track clouds even in the dark.
Satellites do a pretty good job mapping the size and shape of a cloud, and they can even determine its height within a mile or so.
But seeing inside the clouds or below them is still a big challenge.
Pavolonis says airlines would ideally like to know how clean the air is below the bulk of the cloud, but that's tricky.
Gravity is always working on it and so it's always falling.
And so you may always have some ash falling out, so flying under may never be the best option anyhow.
Research flights occasionally go up and sample air to get a better sense of how much ash is up there, and to get a better idea of its composition.
